Review Text: We were told all trains were full at the ticket office which I subsequently do not believe as we were herded to the tourist office where lo and behold they had tickets. We were railroaded into buying a tour which was overpriced and not what we wanted to do. We are independent travellers and found ourselves unwittingly on the tourist trail. The train was empty which confirmed our suspicions that the 'train full' declaration was the beginning of the scam. The accommodation that was booked for us was substandard and we were not even told where we were staying so we could research. If you do end up at the tourist office, which is likely if you don't have prebooked tickets, ask lots of questions about the tour and don't let them railroad you into something you don't want to. I would suggest that you book tickets way in advance, perhaps book a hotel and get them to book tickets over the phone.
Very tired, rundown station lacking almost every facility you should expect . Do not linger! Serious investment need ed.

i am grading this station good rather than poor because considering how busy it is, it operates fairly smoothly in the general context of travel in Sri Lanka. The present station was opened in the early 20th Century and is the major rail hub of the country. Very many commuter trains depart from here as well as the longer routes operated by Sri Lanka Railways. Generally one can find ones way around but be prepared for crowds, a degree of pushing, and taking care.

We took Podi Manike (leaving Fort at 5.55am) to Diyathalawa with a group of 16 including 8 teenage kids. The train travel and the scenery was breathtaking and the overall experience was excellent. We took the first class and the train was pretty much on time. Negative was the toilets which were smelly and not very clean. Most annoying thing was the hassle we had to go through to secure 16 tickets. If there is such a heavy demand wonder why the CGR does not put more trains on this sector as they could easily fill many 1st and 2nd class compartments without much trouble.

We were leaving for Bentota and bought our tickets in advance, not knowing how it worked. Basically, only 1st class will get you reserved seats, but you must do this in advance and through an agency - check on-line. It will cost you considerably more, but its still cheap. Otherwise, you buy a 2nd class ticket, and tickets to destinations 1-2 hours' distant are cheaper than a tube ride in London. Don't expect to get a seat, but relax - once you get on (it may seem daunting, but just move forward), settle in a place (by the doors are preferable for air and views, but between the seats is okay, too). Expect vendors and some beggars to walk around and over you - the cut pineapple and pomengranite seemed safe enough and delicious. Note: Upon returning to Colombo, passengers getting on the train will not wait for you to disembark first. Look to see where Sri Lankans are exiting and follow them. Although it can be stressful, it was a pleasure feeling the air through the open doorways. There's usually a local hanging out the door behind you, so not too much worry about falling out. It's also a great opportunity to meet other travellers.

The railway station has its own beauty and attractiveness. The booking clerks are efficient, fares are exceedingly low, trains are very frequent on the busier lines such as to Mt Lavinia while passengers do not push and shove too much. For some trains to secure a seat it can be best to board at Maradana if that is an option.  Reserving a seat is better but not possible for every train. On platform one there are good kiosks selling snacks, drinks and other requisites.  The language barrier can be present, so try to look for a man dressed in a suit or a well dressed woman as they are the ones more likely to comprehend English.

Fort Railway Station is the Transportation Hub of Sri Lanka built by English.You will end up here if you take a train in or out of Colombo. Transportation is plentiful outside the station, by either Taxi or TukTuk. Train travel is a very convenient and cheap way to travel through Sri Lanka.  You could travel to several destinations in luxury and at a low rate using the Expo Rail. You can find a train to Kandy, Negombo, Galle, Anuradhapura, Trincomale, Baticoloa and Jaffna from here. Luxury trains with AC also are available here to serve you. Take care about your valuables from the  thieves outside the station. I have used Colombo Fort Rail station very often and it has been fine. I live in Kandy and work in Colombo and I travel home and back by trains and I have to come here as the trains start the journeys from here. Finding the correct platform and train seat was very simple.Travelling by train is comfortable and enjoyable and fast as they are not held up due to traffic. In most occasions, Ihave used this station. They will announce about the journey of the train in Sihala, Tamil and in English languages.  I have gone on train to visit many places like Kandy, Badulla, Anuradhapura, Matara and Jaffna using the Sri Lankan railway service. it is low cost and a very efficient way to view the beauty of Sri Lanka. The station has many ticket counters and all are numbered, Above all, there is a list of places they stop and the cost involved for the journey to different destinations.  There are different Numbered ticket counters for different routes and they are nicely notified by signboards. If in doubt go to counters 6 or 7 which are the inquiry counters where you can get help or even ask the schedules. We traveled on the Sri Lankan trains to Hikkaduwa, Galle, Kandy and Negombo and had no problems at all finding the train times and getting the correct trains. 500 or 1000 LKR notes are best for the ticket counters as the train prices are very cheap in Sri Lanka.There is a digital board displaying the time schedules of the trains destination at a particular time. If you travel to "Nuwara Eliya" you get  absolutely beautiful scenery. Cost was 2200 Rupee's in the 1st.class with meals and drinks. Took approximately  6 hours and I loved every minute of it.You'll certainly enjoy the experience. Train travel whilst in Sri Lanka is a must. Much more pleasant than catching the buses but having continuity in ticket prices and bookings does not exist. First class gives you air conditioning and generally a seat (not too crowded) but best to only have carry-on luggage. Third class is with many people as possible. Once you have your ticket go through the entrance and there is a large screen which will tell you the platform number, it changes between Sri Lanka and English every 30 seconds or so. When on the correct platform you can ask a member of staff which end of the platform the carriages for 2nd or 3rd class will arrive. Once the train starts to appear pick you bags up and get ready for the rush to the door. People rush to get into the train which is  no different to â€˜rushâ€™ hour at any station in the world. Keep your ticket as you will need to hand it in when you get off the train. The trains are heavily used in Sri Lanka so if you are slow getting on you may not have a seat. If so, and you donâ€™t mind standing, you can stand by the open carriage doors which is a great way to see the country side pass by. You can either use the  website or instead just go to the station to book the tickets. But better to inquire beforehand the time schedule of the train to your destination if it is a long distance one. Try to get an â€˜expressâ€™ train rather than a â€˜slowâ€™ train as they are slow. If you have the time and like the countryside, you must take a trip on the railways from Colombo Fort, It is worth a peek inside, if you are not traveling, there are public restrooms as well. I recommend you to start your journey from Fort station in the train to your destinations.
Beautiful building still actively used since the mid 1800â€™s. Building itself is nice but operation is crowded and feels chaotic. Kinda dirty.

Had a return train journey booked pre floods to Kandy for 3 days. Given the floods I kept and eye on updates and their website. Also checked with plantation stay we had planned. The train couldnâ€™t reach Kandy but the stop prior . That was ok for us as the hotel said they would pick us up from there. The hotel and I kept checking with the railway and the website right up to 6 hours pre departure. On arrival at the station we were informed that the trains were cancelled due to line work ! We could have got the 4am train and we could get the one at 2pm . Was told at first that the website I looked at was fake! Pointed out that it was the same site I booked and received my tickets from! Then told that they donâ€™t update the website! Welcome to the 21st century. The still manager seemed to find it all very funny. sitting there grinning at me. Whatâ€™s more the hotel informed me that tickets were still available to buy for that trip!  The railway set up is a shambles , we had looked forward to this rail trip and one of the main reasons for visiting Sri Lanka. I understand floods canâ€™t be helped but giving false and misleading information can. We ended up having to do the the 3hr trip by taxi. The farce didnâ€™t end there . Another trip to Galle was booked (1st class not available ) . We booked 2nd class which should have guaranteed a seat , yeah right ! Might just as well spat in the wind. Still they carried on selling 2nd class tickets . Donâ€™t bother with the toilets either , a hole in the floor to the tracks! We travelled rail in so many countries , this is without doubt the worst. Also beware of scammers on these  journeys waiting to pounce on unsuspecting travellers to lead them on to other scammers at the destination .. they work as teams .

We used the old red train and booked in the observation coach. It was absolutely fantastic. A truly wonderful experience. We booked through agents so the tickets were quite pricey. Unfortunately it is impossible to book directly online. You have to go to the station to buy tickets. The journey took 10 hours and we loved the entire trip. Take along food and water. There is no restaurant on the train. Toilets were reasonably clean. Avoid the blue trains if you want an authentic Sri Lankan experience. We left 10 minutes late and arrived an hour late. The officials at Colombo train station were helpful and spoke good English.

ambalangoda train station to columbo and back gain what an experience. The journey up took 2.5hrs on the train which is only slightly longer if not slightly faster than going by taxi but a lot cheaper. Reminds me of traveling on the northern line during rush hour as the train can get packed like sardines. Especially on the way back as we left around 18:15pm to get back. We went left out the station and headed to the Hilton for some lunch and much needed luxury for my fellow travellers then back to the station as there is an indoor market /bazaar which is good for bartering. Across the road and to the right of the station is the busier markets and definitely worth a visit.

This station served the commuters who travel daily from their hometown to the city center every day during weekdays. In addition it also served tourist who travels down south from Colombo. It is a classic building with classic touch.

We met there for a guided tour which was supposed to be street food. Unfortunately our agent here in Australia failed to understand that it was a public holiday for new year. So our guide took us to many spots which were open. This was a really great look around Colombo while it was really really quiet.

where time stands still ... many old fashioned low tech antique operation.. but efficient and used by nearly 500,000 people everyday.. its an place one would fall in love with if you are in to it... felt like i had visited the Hogsmeade Station in a harry potter movie... i urge everyone to take the train ride from this station to Ella.. you will feel like you are on the Hogwarts express
there is a local market next to it which makes this place a must visit, never went inside the station, but the local market was very cheap.

Main station in Colombo for all trains.  Not as hectic as otsher stations we have been to in many other places.  Good to arrive early for onward journey to become orientated but all platforms easy to find.

This train station is located near the Pettah Market where I could walk from. Traffic was terrible and crossing the street is another story so I decided to ride a tuktuk. There are windows here where I was able to buy my round trip train tickets for Kandy. It has some shops to buy snacks, public toilets and few benches to sit down while waiting for the train. Lots of locals use it for their daily commutes. Interesting to watch passengers boarding and getting off the trains here. There are staff to ask here about the correct tracks and train cars to board.

I live in Colombo and this is an place never developed. My advice to travelers, donâ€™t take trishow when you travel in Colombo, unless they are willing to switch on the meter for you. If not install Uber or pick me to your phone and order one. Train times changes frequently, so keep your ear on the speaker who announce the time table, sometimes they may not tell in English too. always better to talk to some passenger (a decent man/women preferably) and keep him informed that you intends to catch-up the particular train. So they will help you. Donâ€™t worry majority of Sri Lankanâ€™s are very helpfull and does not expect something in return.
This ancient railway station is technically the main railway station in Colombo, and is able to connect you effectively to cities such as Kandy and Galle easily.
This station is a turning point for plenty of srilankan's and foreigners as well. :)   Be careful with you wallets and devices :)

This station does not have the flair what it should have from the old times,however one can see the busy life in a capital city's main station Old locs and trainswhich would go with the place are missing. Very helpful staff  at the station and  for round trips in the country try railway tours organising rail+drive tours with reasonable price and reliable drivers. They have their office next to the main entrance

Due to major rail replacement work that commenced in January 2024 and is expected to last for six months, there are currently no trains running from Colombo to Jaffna. Although the main train website is supposed to provide updated information, it continues to show live running trains daily, which is misleading. Train companies need to promptly update their website with accurate and current information. I only learned about the disruption after visiting the Colombo Fort main station and inquiring in person, highlighting the necessity for better communication to avoid inconvenience for passengers.

We had pre-booked tickets for the train to Kandy via an agency and had to pick them up before the train left and since it was a 7 am train, we took no chances and went the day before. EVER so easy. Just showed the confirmation details and my passport and the guy handed over the tickets for this and another trip later in our holiday.  We double checked the platform - number 2 - and came back the next morning. Staff were all very helpful and I was happy we didn't need to drag our bags over the bridge. Some other reviewers have said it's a dirty and chaotic place. Perhaps it's all about perspective. I've been using trains in India for over 20 years and by comparison, Fort station is paradise. We even had time for coffees and samosas from the canteen - which was a good decision as there's no food on the trains. Actually the station was the best part of the journey. Note to self: "Stop forgetting that you really do hate trains". Going backwards for two and a half hours in the freezing cold (thought there was supposed to be no AC in the Observation car) being jiggled about was torture.

Amazing way to view the hustle and bustle of Sri Lanka. The 2nd class trains are pretty stuffy and from where I boarded (Colombo) I did not manage to get any seats. Had  to stand for 2.5 hours to get to Bentota. Not ideal for families or kids. Ideal for backpackers for travellers on a budget . Tickets are really affordable though. TIP: Go to the railway station to check on the tickets. Online site does not help.
The train station staff were very helpful and. Took time to ensure we had the right time and platform for our train

We recently travelled from Colombo to Galle by train with our 2 children aged 10 and 11. The tickets cost 180slr each for 2nd class or 100slr each for 3rd. The journey takes just over 2 hours. The train was busy but not crowed and we easily found seats all together. Its best to get window seats on the side of the ticket office as this will give you a brilliant view when heading down the coast. We bought some water and snacks before we left the station but you can buy small snack items on board including the shrimp fritters that are so popular in Colombo.

This is the best place where you can catch any train towards any part of the country. Usually a crowded place. As many people, local and foreign alike use this place,government should do more for this place. There are canteens that you can get a decent meal but the public toilets are a nightmare. Authorities should attend to that to make this place a more pleasant one for everyone.

The information center offers no real support. Some of the travel suggestions are bad-mouthed and attempts are made to sell a complete travel package including driver and accommodation. For example, we had pre-booked accommodation (Trincomalee) and this was dismissed as a very bad idea. (Monsoon, sea dangerous and the train from there to Habarana only 3rd class with standing room and completely overcrowded) The reality was: Wonderful weather and sea in Trincomalee and the train (we are currently traveling in) 2nd class relatively empty and comfortable. Our other travel ideas were dismissed in the same way. Luckily we did not accept the offer and organized ourselves as planned.

My advices: Don't expect any information about train on it. You must only ask the people. So come erlier. Don't use offered service that tuk-tuk guys with buing Ticket on train. They said me, they buy me it cheaper for observation 1st class car becouse forainers have higher price. I used it, but they bought ticket for 2nd class for regular price not for 1st class! Ticket  seems same. There is allegedly tuk-tuk mafia on it.

The old station is interesting, like most stations it is busy with mostly locals.  We traveled first class to Kandy, not quite what the photos showed on the website but still a good way to get to Kandy cheaply.

We were a little concerned about how getting tickets to Jaffna would go after reading previous reviews. We were aware that we needed the ticket office near platform 17 and when you get to the main frontage of the station ( by the pedestrian bridge over the road) it is clearly signed. I would recommend getting the tickets the day before ( especially for Jaffna as it leaves the station at 5.45am). This takes the stress out of journey. Be focussed on not letting people direct you in different places, it really is clear. When you go in the ticket room the Jaffna desk is right over to the right. I think Kandy etc are more to the left and they had big queues. Oddly hardly any western tourists when we went. Next day we were off early and felt absolutely safe.  We were confused where to go when we arrived as there were a large number of people commuting that frankly just get in the way of trying to get in the station...another reason why you really should get your tickets the day before. A man checked our tickets and directly pointed out where we should stand for our carriage. Far less hassle than we thought. Be prepared for the first class being a relative term!
my trip was wonderful so I like it, also will make it again because of elephants in Nora lay town,musume

Hard to find the ticket booth. Try to avoid the infocenter service, since they will try to sell you a full Sri Lanka tour at very high prices. The law prohibits to sell endstation to endstations tickets of you are just taking a part of the trip, but they did it anyway. So we paid 1000 rp for a 2 hours trip from Nanu Oya to Haputale... Try to buy form the ticket booth directly or ask your hotel for help. The station is right next to the Market and a 10 minute walk to the central bus station (on the opposite side of the street)

Well, it was not their fault for being on strike precisely the day we got there, but the place could do with a lot more cleaning and organizing... Too much dirt and disorganizing to take in from the very first day in Sri Lanka, I'm afraid. Still, if you want to travel by train to Kandy- the best way to take in the fabulous scenery- this is the station to go to.

We got there to get tickets and ended at the tourist information center. Prassana there got us the tickets and recommendations for the trip we planned. He offered us a private driver and, even though it was for us an unexpected expense, it really was the best idea. The driver, Terence, guided us through part of the trip with experience and cordiality. We avoided long hours of transport and made the best of our trip. Terence took us to everywhere and gave us local recommendations, and was a great way to know the country from a local view. Probably not the best option for everyone, but I would undoubtedly recommend it to anyone. Thanks to Terence for everything, we will contact him again if we are lucky enough to be back.

My friend and I are going to Galle and we purchased ticket for the express train to Galle. There was some technical difficulty as the car won't open. It took them 30 minutes to get it together to realize that there was no power coming in that car.

Colombo Fort Station is the main rail gateway to central Colombo, it is the main station of the most intercity trains in the country. Fort Station is situated in the heart of the city, located next to the Colombo Fort and Pettah Market. This is very crowded place, therefore, no one should visit the station to see this station only to see, if not travelling by train. In my view, there is nothing special or interesting things in the station to observe.

Reviewer Location: Ashby de la Zouch, United Kingdom
Review Text: A bustling station with plenty tyo keep you amused for 20 minutes and some interesting framed photo collages of bygone days omn Platform 1.  I had the good fortune to meet the station announcer who took me to observe her at woek and meet her colleagues in the back office
This is a very traditional but very busy railway station which is in need of an upgrade and  a huge clean up.  There was only one booth selling snacks and drinks.

By far the best and cheapest way to get from Colombo to Kandy. If you splash out on a first class ticket it's comfortable too and you get fantastic views from the observation carriage. There are A/C buses but the roads can be very busy and the journey time can take anywhere from 4-6 hours depending on time of travel and traffic levels. You can also take a private car of course but you're faced with the same traffic/time issues and the cost is likely to be around 8,000 Rs. I highly recommend the train.

As a tourist if you choose to travel to your desired destination by train, you ll probably have to come to the Colombo Fort Railway station. But often its not easy for a foreign national given the lack of digital or printed signboards or service personnel. Obviously you can try your luck asking for help from locals on which train is where, or whether the train is the right one. But always preferable to re-confirm with 2-3 ppl before you board. Bring your own food and drinks. Even if you dont happen to be traveling and say you are a photographer, the Fort Railway is an excellent place to get some snaps, in fact one of the best in the city. The building itself is historical, and the everyday commuters, the busy train schedules,  provide excellent subjects.

Main railway hub of the country and terminus for all intercity trains. A similar architectural design to Manchester Victoria station in England. Well preserve old colonial look has grabbed attention of many photographers. However, food and sanitary facilities here are not the best. If you're strict hygiene concerned, better avoiding. But, trip to Sri Lanka is not completed if didn't catch a train from here to central highlands,specially Kandy, Nuwaraeliya and Ella. These are the most scenic routes one should never missed. Or you can opt for southern coastal route as well.
Entire Sri lanka is well connected by rail  and one of the cheapest modes of travel. During peak hours it is pretty crowded.
Wash rooms are not repairing. Unclean and very dirty.  So many passengers coming to fort railway station every day. It is very bad situation

British built Central Railway Station with the Train seat Booking centre located for tickets to all parts of Sri Lanka . The typical British type construction prevails reminding one of the days gone by . The Railway Museum in the vicinity is interesting . Room for improvement and cleanliness despite the thousands who patronize the station daily .
It was not very clean the infrastructure was shabby, the announcements are not clear. no clear signages to understand about the train movements. if you are a tourist you need to try your luck.

Firstly, the population that uses trains has probably not increased since the Brits first built this thing. It is so much fun to see the station in almost its original beauty and with so few people around (it seems no one uses the trains), it allows you to explore the place at your own pace taking in every little detail. Great place if you like going back in time every now and then :)

Caught the train from Colombo to Kandy.   Great part of our adventure of touring Sri Lanka - albeit dirty, noisy and definitely no class system at all.... but a great way to travel as driving takes forever.  We pre-booked the 1st class observation carriage on-line at home - you get reserved seats which is a MUST if you are joining these hectic, hot and overcrowded trains, and you pick the tickets up at the station.  Comfy enough seats - good views along the way.  An experience not to miss.  And oh so cheap.   1st class less than a Fiver....

The station is in the Pettah area which is a wonderful crazy, busy market. Spent a couple of hours wandering around and being assailed by the noise and general chaos - wonderful if you want to break away from traditional tourist activities
Its interesting to know about the public lifestyle of Sri Lankans. Most of the people come for work daily use the railway from very far from Colombo.

Fort Railway Station is a major rail hub and the main rail gateway to central Colombo (here most intercity trains running over the country end) For the information, Fort Station is a couple kilometres away from Maradana Station, the other major rail station in Colombo. USEFUL & PRO TIP Not many people knows that in Colombo there are also metered tuk-tuks, which are the fairest way to move around the city. Therefore, make yourself sure to get on one of these if you want to avoid to be ripped off.
The only way to travel to out stations through trains. Beware of pickpocketers as they are almost everywhere.
In Sri Lanka people mostly use trains because of low cost and fast transportation. But it has limited locations to travel by train. But if you will travel by train it will be great experience.

1 of the centres of Colombo. As a tourist train journeys is 1 of the best ways to travel around Sri Lanka. Trains from here go everywhere in Sri Lanka connected by train. I found biking a train here pretty easy and people here speak good English. If you arrive here ton of tuk-tuks and buses to bring you anywhere in Colombo.

All long distance trains which include trains down South , up North to Jaffna and to the Central Hills start here. Train travel is the cheapest.  Very good value for money even if you book 1st class with AC. 2nd class (without AC) is equally comfortable if you are travelling to the cool climate of the hills. It's best to book online before travelling as trains tend to get crowded. ...3rd class travellers often have to stand. It's a great place to people watch as busy commuters come into the city to work and families with kids go on trips in the school holidays. ...
all long far trains are starting from colombo,specially upcountry, north east and east,well schedule

I travelled by train to Kandy from Colombo. We booked in advance through Expo rail. Glad I did because not everyone got tickets, but saying that we were travelling 1st class and most locals travel 2nd or 3rd. Finding the expo rail ticket counter was a little difficult but we we asked at a counter they were super friendly and helpful. Expo Rail is counter 17. It is behind a door unlike all the other counters. There were people everywhere but it was easy to find our platform and felt safe. Train travel in Sri Lanka is an experience and think everyone should do it.

It is as busy as any other station but the streets are covered with stalls and there are no decent restaurants near the station.. However, the staff of the station is very tourist friendly and helpful.. Had been there to catch the rajdhani express for Kandy. It is not a tourist attraction.

If you are travelling from the Colombo to any city via train then probably the station you could catch the train is Colombo fort.there are 9 platform available and each have been numbered . Once you enter to the station on the 4 rd platform you could found the digital railway time table and it includes the train destaination ,departure time and the platform number which train arrived. When it comes to sanitary facilities ghee are number of toilets avaialable and the toilets in the first platform are clean compared to others.there are 2 rest rooms for ladies and gents separately. Also 2 canteens available in the 3 rd platform.

We used the Colombo Fort Railway Station to travel to Kandy. We had already reserved seats online but as you need to exchange the online booking confirmation for tickets to travel we had to wait for the sales desk to open. We arrived at 6am (our train was scheduled to leave at 7am). The sales office opened at 6am but no one came to the desk until 0640hrs! There was a mad dash and lots of pushing and shoving but we did manage to get our tickets and the staff on the platform and on the train were very helpful.
This is the main railway station of sri lanka and connects you with ella and galle. Come early to get tickets, well organised

From the Colombo Fort Railway Station we took the train to Kandy. It took us like 10 minutes to find the right Gate... As soon as the train arrived, everyone ran to get a place- luckily we booked some private seats! At the trains door was a man, telling us where our seats are (thought this was a staff member...) but as soon as everyone was sitting, he went around, signing that he is deaf, working in a deaf school and wants/needs money... no problem- but the way he did was just unreasenable! We gave him 1000 Rupees but then he looked as this wasnt enough for him!

It is quite an experience to take the train in Sri Lanka. This train station is much bigger than the one in Nuwara Eliya, you can see the lotus tower from the platforms, quite busy as well, there are trains going to almost anywhere. The coast line is pretty, also a little sad to see those roughly built houses... we stopped at a station thatâ€™s about 1 h away from Colombo, the ride going there was nice, train was not crowded at all, a lot of empty seats, but the ride back to Colombo was packed, so if you want to do that be prepared. The station looks really old, some trains are rusty from inside out, but they are still running, and look beautiful in a photo. I believe time has filled this place with stories, go and feel it yourself.
Main station in sri lanka. cleanliness is really poor. Have to make this place more pleasant coz we are a tourist destination
The Fort Station has a rustic and olden age feel, but the services and standard of the station and Sri Lankan trains need to Improve slot. Don't even think of using the washroom at this place.

This is the central of all trains and the trains in Sri Lanka is really cheap but they are without aircond. It can get really crowded. I ended up sitting on the floor of the train but it isnt too dirty. As for this station, it is near Pettah Market area. Everything is nearby too, the Dutch Hospital Mall, Ministry of Crab in Dutch Hospital and Crescat Mall. You can very well get a cheap tuktuk to get you anywhere nearby or just take a train. We also went to Kandy from here. Second class (sat on the floor) was 40LKR. To get to Kompanna Vidya where our hotel is was 10LKR. Even if you dislike the hot crowded trains, try experiencing it at least once. It is safe. You can walk around Colombo Fort area. There are a lot of stalls nearby selling fruits, food, juice, cloth, handmade crafts etc.

Visited colombo in the month of Jan. Colombo fort station is a busy station. Went for a small ride in the coastal line. The stations in the coastal lines are old but with wi fi :) Looks like malgudi days station. My friends from India could relate. The train line is actually on the coast, you can see the sea on one side of the train, and road on the other side. Loved the sunset view from train. There are shops near fort station where yoy can buy leather staff and magnets and other souveniers for really good deals. ENSURE THAT IF YOU ARE TRAVELLING BY AN AUTO, ALWAYS GO BY METER.

Built by the British, so fairly functional and durable, but in need of upkeep. Could also do with (clearer) English signs and announcements and more food/drink stalls at all times of the day and night. Very clean though, compared to a lot of other stations in South Asia. Surrounding region has street markets that are worth a visit.

We just went to see what goes on with the trains in Sri Lanka.  It was interesting.  There are 3 or 4 classes of trains, and they all pretty much are old, dirty and run down. We booked 2nd Class reserved seats from Colombo Fort Station to Kandi by making a phone call to the Fort Railway Station. We were quoted the correct price, given a receipt number and informed that we could pick the tickets up on arrival at the railway station. We travelled by taxi from our accommodation in Negombo, heavily laden with backpacks and additional day packs, and arrived leaving an hour before the scheduled 8.30 departure time on Good Friday March 30, 2018. After locating the appropriate ticket counter (Counter 17), we were told that there were no tickets booked for us, the receipt number was incorrect and there were no available seats on that train or any train to Kandy on that or subsequent days. As there was a line of other customers behind us, we left the counter and went to the Railway Tourist Information Office next door. The office was not yet open but a helpful person told us that we could put our bags down inside and wait for someone to help us. We accepted the offer, respite from a crowded footpath and a seat in an air conditioned office. After making his morning offerings, a man named Sampath told us that he would inquire about the availability of tickets for us. He came back some time later with the information that there were no vacancies on the 8.30 train as it was a very busy holiday, but he would see if he could get us tickets on a later train. He made one or more phone calls and told us that it would be possible to get tickets for reserved seats on the 10.30 train. After much coming and going we he returned and revealed that the seats were available only as part of a package holiday involving accommodation and drivers/guides. As we had already booked accommodation in Kandy, he "helpfully" put together an itinerary based on our travel plans. We were a little surprised at the quoted costs but, as new arrivals in the country and feeling trapped in Colombo on one of the busiest travel days of the year, were in a good position to be exploited. We agreed to a much shortened and cheaper version of the 15 day package that was offered. The full package cost the equivalent of (Australian) $1 700 for 15 days. This exceeded our budget and did not match our desire to plan our travel as we discovered more about the country and what we wanted to do in it. The final deal was for 2 one way tickets to Kandy, 4 nights of accommodation in Sigiriya, and a driver/guide to drive us from Kandy to Sigiriya, to our destinations for the next 4 days and back to Kandy on the last day. While we waited for the process to play out and our tickets to be obtained we observed the same scam being used on a succession of European and Asian travellers by the other officials in the Information Office. The accommodation in Sigiriya was good but the driver, while seemingly friendly, offered very limited advice or details and at every opportunity tried to persuade us to go to costly tourist attractions and buy safari and village tours, which we declined. We have since discovered that the accommodation was owned by the "tourist information officer" and he has been using this as his main source of bookings for a long time. This scam is well known to many within the tourism sector in Sri Lanka and is not limited to Colombo Fort Station. The cost of both the accommodation and driver were inflated, so that the 76 000 rupee ($A 654) we paid was well in excess of what we would have paid by independently booking. Stick to information from the official government tourist offices which are located at the airport and in a number of cities throughout Sri Lanka. They do not receive commissions or kick backs, offer good advice to travellers, are very well informed and put together itineraries that match your interests and allow you to see everything possible in the budget and timelines available to you. They also book you excellent  drivers that (while not seemingly cheap) have great knowledge that they enthusiastically impart. We found the accommodation bookings they arranged for us to always exceed our expectations.

For starters, you will have to enter in a room to get tickets for Ella/Nuwara Eliya and that small room is full of chaos. It's full of people pushing each other with no one to tell you what queue to join. People can be often seen cutting queues here and there is no official to keep track of it. When you go inside the station you will see it's too crowded. There is a small snack shop which charges more than the MRP. At least at the railway station I would have expected some kind of regulation (which is missing in the rest of Sri Lanka anyway). A 1.5 L water bottle was being sold for 80 LKR when the MRP mentioned was 70 LKR. I raised this with the man at the counter to which he gave some crazy explanation. Since you cannot go out of the station once you have entered (they take your ticket back on your way out), you don't have a choice but to buy water or other essentials from here if you forgot to buy them outside. There is a bridge to access different platforms on the station. However, the locals rarely follow the bridge. Most people go from above the train tracks even though it has been clearly mentioned not to do so. There is a very small waiting room which is almost always crowded. It's better to sit on the benches than in the waiting room. Try to book tickets in advance and come to the station only 15 minutes prior to the departure of your train.

On arriving at the station we was pointed to the Tourist Information Centre for help obtaining our ticket. We met Prasanna who was a very good help because the train we wanted to catch was full but got us sorted on the next train in comfortable seats with air con. At this point he started talking about booking a tour through him "we thought here we go" After a lengthy chat and giving us some figures "which sounded a very good deal" we decided to book and I'm glad we did. We would have never been able to see as much of Sri Lanka so easily without this tour. It was arranged for our driver to pick us up from our hotel in Kandy and that he did. This is when we met Lahiru Dissanayaka our driver and tour companion for 5 days. Lahiru was an absolute godsend and became a very good friend over them 5 days. We saw everything possible in the time we had and Lahiru's knowledge of the places we visited was exceptional. We saw everything we could from our Kandy City tour on our first day. Kandy to Nuwara Eliya on our second day. Nuwara Eliya to Matale, Dambulla and Sigiriya on our third. A jeep Safari at Polonnaruwa "we saw so many elephants, it was a beautiful sight" and all the ancient ruins on our fourth. On our fifth day Lahiru took us from Sigiriya to the drop off point of our choice which was a long trek to Trincomalee seeing and stopping at some beautiful sights on our way. It was sad to see Lahiru go and I would highly recommend Rail Tours to see all the beautiful sights of Sri Lanka at a very good price. Just take your time when your in the office and point out what you want to see and when and you won't be disappointed. A big thank you to Rail Tours and a bigger thank you to Lahiru Dissanayaka.

This station was staffed by friendly helpful people but was very chaotic and confusing, The toilets were the worst I that I saw during my 5 weeks in Sri Lanka, they do have tourist toilets but they were locked and they could not find the key holder! A couple of booths selling snacks and drinks but nothing else, so grab drinks and snacks or fruit from the shops outside the station.

We were about to get our tickets to Galle and the tourist information office just wanted to sell their tours. They do offer. Great customer service but sometimes itâ€™s better to do your own consultation before believing on what they say.
Still this place should be more improved. especially wash rooms. some time back they were collecting money from the users of wash rooms and there was no any significant improvement.

It is just like a Railway Station like Mumbai's CST Raillway.  But certainly not that great archiitrctural value.  The surroundings are just like any of the moderately big Railway Stations in India, surrounded with shops, eateries etc.

We got an Uber from Negombo to Colombo fort station in the rush hour which took  1 hour and 20 minutes. We arrived at 9am and there was no queue for second class ticket at no. 3 counter. The ticket inspector told us which platform to go to. When the train arrived we knew 2nd class was at the front but the train didnâ€™t come right to end of platform, so we had to walk further up to get in. On previous trip advisor advice we took the first seats we found and had a good journey. A few people who arrived later had to stand so the train was full but not overcrowded

Colombo Fort is not a world class Station by any stretch of the imagination, but it's nowhere near the worst either. I had pre booked tickets (prior to leaving Australia) and went to Colombo Fort the day before travelling to collect the tickets. The Station is quite easy to navigate, and they even have an office for Tourist Info.

They seemed recently renewed the luggage storage. There are no wooden lockers anymore but are morgue-like steel lockers with keys. They said they close at 7:30 pm. Also, be aware of the scam. We were only here for about 20 minutes before our train to Kandy. Found it easy enough to buy a ticket at one of the counters for second class (someone had recommended ticket counter 17 but we just went to the first one at it was fine). Inside I used the toilet before heading on the train as I wasn't sure there would be one on it. There was a 'ladies waiting room' area and it had toilets inside. Pretty horrible toilets but it was a toilet - I've been to worse! The train station was pretty busy but the staff helped direct us to the right train. Our train departed about 10 minutes late which was fine. The journey from Colombo to Kandy is beautiful and took about 3.5 hours. We were on a blue train (I'm sure they have a name but I don't know it!) in second class and it was pretty comfy and not as busy as I thought. The train board outside said all trains were FULL, so we thought it was going to be manic! But there were loads of empty seats on our carriage. Oh, and the blue trains do have a toilet if anyone is worried about a long journey or going with children.

Such a busy station, good to people watch!  Would recommend using the bathrooms if you don't desperately need to go.  If you need a tuk tuk beware of the drivers as you exit.  They will refuse to use meters and will overcharge.  Make sure you barter and do not accept their first price.  We asked away from many.  We were given 600-1000 rupees in price to our hotel, ended up paying 300.

What can I say about Colomboâ€™s Fort Railway station other then, if you have only been to a train station in a developed country then you are in for a shock!  The way to enjoy it is to just go with the flow.  The station itself is easy to find and all tuk-tuk drivers know where it is. The station has many ticket counters, all numbered, and above which is a list of places they stop and the cost.  If in doubt go to counters 6 or 7 which are the inquiry counters where you can get help.  We travelled on the Sri Lankan trains to Hikkaduwa, Galle, Kandy and Negombo and had no problems at all finding the train times and getting the correct trains.  500 or 1000 LKR notes are best for the ticket counters as the train prices are very cheap in Sri Lanka.  Once you have your ticket go through the entrance and there is a large screen which will tell you the platform number, it changes between Sri Lanka and English every 30 seconds or so. When on the correct platform you can ask a member of staff which end of the platform the carriages for 2nd or 3rd class will arrive.  Once the train starts to appears pick you bags up and get ready for the rush to the door.  There will not be any manners shown, so it will be every man, woman and child for yourself. (No different to â€˜rushâ€™ hour at any station in the world).  Keep your ticket as you will need to hand it in when you get off the train. The trains are heavily used in Sri Lanka so if you are slow getting on you may not have a seat.  If so, and you donâ€™t mind standing, you can stand by the open carriage doors which is a great way to see the country side pass by. We didnâ€™t use the website instead just went to the station to book the tickets. PS. Try to get an â€˜expressâ€™ train rather than a â€˜slowâ€™ train as they are slow.

Going thru the train station was an easy and pleasant experience. Arrived well in advance finding the platform was a non issue and mixing in the morning life a real delight. Catching the train was also easy and helped by locals if needed be. The place is a paradise for photographers catching local life in morning light.

The Station is clean and connects to all parts of Sri Lanka where trains travel. Reservations can be made on Main lines at the reservations Counter ( Counter No 17). Better to decide prior to your journey and reserve your seats in advance at least 25 to 30 days ahead as Train Journeys are very popular and gets fully booked in no time.
If you are travelling to Kandy, take the second class carriage. You will get a seat, you can open the windows and an overall very enjoyable experience for seeing the sights and taking photos.

I had read reviews before going to the train station and they seemed very mixed of good and bad experiences. We got to the train station with about 40 mins to spare for our train at 10.30 from Colombo to Galle. It was easy to get a ticket and cost us each 180 for second class tickets. The guy at the platform told us which platform to go to as our train hadnâ€™t even appeared on the board. Once on the train it was very busy and we ended up standing for the first hour but luckily people got off at different stations and we got a seat eventually. The train ride is about 2 and a bit hours, itâ€™s not that comfortable and the toilet is basically a hole that goes straight on the tracks which we found to be an experience in its self ðŸ˜‚. Once at Galle, it is good to look when the trains are back the next day. Itâ€™s not a trip you can do in a day as the last train back seems to be around 3/4pm. Many people try to help you saying they work at the station but usually they do help but then have another agenda e.g. then try get you to take a taxi with them. On our way back to Colombo we ended up getting the bus back as we would have had to wait 2 hours for the train and we both weâ€™re not looking forward to the journey again. Some men tried to get us to get in a taxi for 5000 which seemed cheap but in comparison to the train ticket it is not. In the end we just went to the bus station to ask and found a bus straight away the price was 340 each to get to Colombo which we took as we were confirmed seats, air con and was definitely a more comfort drive. We asked if we could get dropped off earlier then Colombo as we would have driven past our accommodation and it was fine to do that. It may take an hour longer to get to each destination but definitely more comfortable and I would recommend looking at getting the bus both ways.

This is the Oldest Railway station in Sri Lanka. Initiated in 1864, sandwiched between two roads namely Henry Steel Olcott Mawatha and  MacCallum Road. A small peninsula in the Beira Lake. Very old Victorian architecture is visible but with very poor or no maintenance. Recent developments to the Railway platforms are encouraging. Communication system is very hash, blurred and unclear. Smelly toilets and unfriendly staff. Ticket counter clerks are caged in like monkeys and throw the tickets and change to the travelers. Not customer friendly or Oriented. Very poorly maintained. Rail tracks are full of used tickets,paper.empty PVC bottles etc, Cleaning had not being done for years.Very old photographs are sited in wrong places, difficult to enjoy them as crowds gather there to exit. Improper or no layout plans is playing a big role here.

This Railways Station is the main Fort Railway In Colombo to take different part of the city to travel a small Tourist information office available, need more computerize system to be update specially for tourist. its not well maintain. need more care an attention.

Very old style rail station. Does the job but if the waiting time is more then it is real pain. It is clean though and you get drinking water bottles and some snacks. There was a oldish restaurant but we did not check it out.

This is the main Railway station in the capital Colombo.You can catch a train to any part of the Island.Srilanka has many good train routes.Like any major railway station this station is also surrounded by many food outlets.

An easy train experience compared to some other places in the region. Just be careful when trains arrive of course, as people can get very pushy coming off and on. Just wait back when the train arrives, it's not worth it to push and shove for a seat. There is always room to stand, and nobody will push or shove you if you are ok with sitting on the floor, or next to the door (best views).

since 18 th century. british people build colonial style station. for any destination to start trainne journes start from this place. 24 hrs open. affter enter this place not very clean and maintaining.specialy monday to friday morning 7am to 9am &  evening 4 pm to 7pm sooooo busy.......

The station is hectic but no where near as India. Ground staff are most helpful helping us with our luggage into the cabin and locating our seat. Ticket office needs improvement to reduce waiting times, would be great to buy tickets online; maybe there is a way but we couldnâ€™t give a way

We came here to catch a train to kandy. Got our prepaid tickets validated and left our packs in the left luggage for 300 rupees (byo lock- we borrowed one from the man) while we walked around town. Was fine and easy to catch train. Toilets skankin.  (Awful)

Travelling to the North and Upcountry is more comfortable when you travel in an Air conditioned first class compartment. These carriages have adjustable seats which can also be rotated to face the direction of travel, or to face each other when travelling as a group, with adequate leg space. The 5.45am train to jaffna is a fully air conditioned one. All three trains heading to Badulla via Kandy on the upcountry line, have one air-conditioned compartnent. Special weekend trains to Kandy and back are also fully air conditioned.

Recently I traveled to Badulla with my family as we wanted to  see the hill country Through Observation car windows. The journey was nearly 12 hours. Will you believe if I say there is no place for  a meal in this train. Early days there was a canteen called Buffet. Now it is not there. The train stops at Nawalapitya and in that station there is a canteen. I bought a Mango Nectar bottle and tasted horrible. No need to talk about their food.The fans in the observation car some were not working. unfortunately we were under one of them. The toilet was terrible. I had to was the toilet for my family members. I felt shame as there were some foreigners in the compartment. Can not understand why nobody wants to improve the conditions. It is better if the ticket issuers inform the commuters when they are booking the seats that the facilities they get when they travel. Then they could bring a meal packet. Water and drinks from home. I purchased tickets both ways and The Guard who was in the Colombo Badulla was really nice and helpful. He was acting like a tour guide.

Hub for all long distance trains.  Was very busy, asked at tourist information about the train we wanted and were told it was full and to get a later train.  We asked the ticket seller, got tickets, got on, got seats and had a very nice trip to Rambukana.  Don't believe tourist information.

Counter 17 for reservations. Even if they tell you a train is fully booked, go there at 5 am when the office opens and, unless you are a he group - you will surely get a seat on the train to Ella. Tuk tsk drivers outside the station are among the most dishonest in Sri Lanka so be careful and perhaps get the metered ones.

Really busy environment. Staff generally unhelpful. Trains dirty and noisy - what more can I say? There are foreigners toilets - which you can get a key for - the locals facilities are shocking...Take care which train you get on - staff will put you on the wrong train...I think its a game they play!
Quaint, clean, no rush and transport easily available at the gates. So convenient for travellers coming in. Trains coming in at the correct time and leaving at the correct time. Good for commuters.
the only place to get in to the train in colombo. At fort if you want to use the toilet this is one of the place you will get a releafe. Pay a ticket for the platform and then you can use the toilet.

The station area is clean, inside and in front, that is very good comparing to stations I have been to f.ex. in India. I also felt safe during my time waiting for the train to Jaffna. Still I was glad that I didn`t need to use the bathroom or had to eat in a restaurant.

Reading reviews here, it is easy to see that some people have experienced various scams. The place is chaotic and it is not clear which queue you should be standing in. My wife and I stood at different windows, in order to get our tickets. She found out that she had been sent  to the wrong one and so signalled me to stay put. We finally got our tickets and enjoyed an exciting train ride to Polonnaruwa. Taking the train is a great way to experience the country, but can be uncomfortable and stressful. This stage of our journey was fine.

Last month (October) we took a train from here at 8.30a.m. to Kandy.  Platform was so easy to locate & there was a gentleman who showed us where to wait & then when the train arrived, he showed us where to get on & find out seats.  Very easy experience compared to stations in India.

Please read the reviews! Tourists Information Centre is a scam! My friend and I booked first class tickets and only to realize the day of our trip that we got third class tickets but PAID for first class! Once we arrived in Hatton, our driver kept rushing us to go home yet we paid for him for 4 days. He didn't work on the first two days (just a drive to the hotel on day one and to and from Adam's Peak on day two). Day three he kept using his phone and then he ran out of the vehicle with his phone and hid behind a rock wall so we wouldn't see him on the phone...we don't speak the language so no need to hide. Both of us felt VERY unsafe with him so we decided not to go with him to Kandy...instead we booked a real first class train ticket. USP Lanka Tours and Travels was the receipt we got from the Colombo Fort Railway Station: Tourists Information Centre (left side of the building). Please book with hotels as they are cheaper and honest! That is what we have learned from out trip....This company is nothing but a scam! TCR is Third Class Reservation and AFC is A/C First Class Reservation. Look at your ticket immediately!
You need to book in advance for first or second class to guarantee a seat otherwise queue on the day two hours prior for third class with no chance of a seat

This is an iconic landmark in the city of Colombo. It is situated in the heart of the business district of Colombo. Most of the trains from other places of Sri Lanka halt here. The station as such is of old colonial style and it has not been remodeled. There are not many platforms and the ticket counters are also few. The entrance is impressive colonial style. Next to the station are a lot of shopping, but don't expect genuine stuff and also the locals don't seem very interested in selling their goods. because they don't expect you to bargain, even though the stuff is fake. The station is very dirty and not at all maintained well. The less said of the trains and the compartments.
The infrastructure has seen better days but the service was generally good. Tannoy messages were not always as clear as they could have been

Prasanna organised a tour around Sri Lanka with the best driver ever.  Professional, knowledgeable  about political and cultural situation.  We are delighted we found them.  First experience with a driver for us and it made our stay so very enjoyable.  We saw much more of Sri Lanka than we expected to see in the time we spent there.  Highly recommend this service. PS we left a charger behind in one hotel and rail tours organised the return for us!
A typical Indian railway station. For Europens must  visit it to understand the local life style. Very crowded.

Just to let you know that if you go south even if you ticket says the train departs from Maradhana, you don't have to go this place. Colombo fort is the second stop so if you take the train at Maradhana Station you'll end up back at Fort in 5/10 mins. Normally is platform 6, blue and white train, be aware that if you buy 3rd class you'll be crammed inside or even hanging outside the door. For first class tickets is another wagon. Be ready.

Nothin special compared to other asian train stations but worth seeing it if you haven't seen another one. The timetables are not electronic but wooden!! Restrooms are seperate for men and women and foreigners. In general it is asian and  colonialistic and exotic without beeing chaotic like some other railway station in this region. You need a ticket to enter the station and see the platforms

this is the railway station after mount lavinia if you are planning to explore the island nation by train. I visited this station since I was travelling to Jaffna by train and boarded my train from this station. as compared to Indian stations these are still backdated. there is no proper announcement system, there are no LCD/ LED indicators indicating which train is arriving when and which platform, the rake positions etc. But it will add up in due course of time I hope. the station exteriors are not that clean as is the rest of the city.

The Colombo Fort Railway Station is the main point of departure for trains to all points of the country such as  Kandy, Nuwara Eliya and Jaffna. Lovely old building which needs TLC. We visited the wooden Tourist Enquiries area where we were given vague information in response to our specific questions. The man became a lot more animated and effective when a couple of 20 something young ladies turned up and it became clear he had put together a private tour for them. There is a government/private JV in relation to this office and we had much better service and replies to our questions at the General Enquiries counter (11) run by the Railway itself . There is a dedicated area (17) to book first class sleeper and observation cars which is split into separate counters for different routes. First class is cheap and the only way to travel by train..! The 3 wheelers immediately outside the station are largely rip off merchants so best to get one dropping people or walk to the main road and make sure you get one with a meter.

This place is the hub of travel from Colombo. At certain times of day it is ok, but not during the rush hours when you will be jostled and squeezed. No lifts of course, so cross the tracks to change platforms. Very old-fashioned. Not well signed. A good place to escape from.
Very neat and clean Railway system.The trains are very good and the station is basic but with very friendly and helpful locals

Located in a busy place. Unfortunately the day i was supposed to go to Galla by train, there was a protest near the railway station leading to terrible traffic. Worst experience in my travel log. Missed the train journey too :(

Train station with lots of movement. initially seems to be very confusing, but the staff give good information, if we are lost with so many counters to buy tickets. The station is also located near the bus station and has commerce around.

This is Sri Lanka's largest railway station, situated as it is, in the heart of the island's commercial district in Colombo. It was built during the colonial era of the mid 19th century, and reminds one of the Victoria Station in London. But the resemblance is fleeting. The station is dirty and drab, and desperately needs a facelift. A continuous maintenance crew is necessary to ensure the cleanliness and functioning of its facilities as it serves a constant stream of office workers and holiday makers throughout the year. No self respecting individual would dare use its waiting rooms or washrooms, the ticket collectors and other officials are indifferent or rude, and rarely does a train arrive or depart on time. Such a pity. So much potential. It is sad when an old building goes to rack and ruin.
This is a historic place and daily use hundreds thousand of commuters. There are lots of facilities have to to be improved including rest rooms, waiting area, and toilets.

Organising a ticket from outside Sri Lanka ie booking online would have been great but not possible from Australia so fortunately Reddot kindly helped us book ahead  but even then we'd hoped for a sleeper but got the seats . We've caught trains , tuk tuks and buses in various Asian countries but what struck me was the station was like entering a mine and I was ready to send my canary in first ! .. poor poor lighting so I was happy to notice a women's waiting room as I'd be a little cautious  if a lone female traveller  due to the darkness although of course as we found throughout Sri Lanka people are very friendly . locating the right train was a little challenging and although very old trains they were clean with clean toilets . The train stops here. And there for mail pick up/ drop off  and at one pint stopped 20 minutes where the local vendors wait for train travellers to sell there food. The hot drink vendor calls along the train " teacoffeeteacoffeeteacoffee" . Bottled water also available from vendor . If you're only going to Polonnarawu you'll need to book a night at a close hotel as the train arrives around 1:30 am so don't anticipate too much sleep on the night train but it's an easy way to get to visit the Cultural Triangle and beyond ... Just make sure you can find your train in the dark .

This being the most common 'first Sri Lankan railway experience' for most travellers, the staff are quite helpful in where to send you for tickets/reservations. The locals are also willing to help you out if you are looking lost! The signage is easy to come across and with Pettah Markets just across the road you can get some cheap food and shopping before you head off.
Dead easy to get your tickets and travel. Found our way to Galle en route to Unawatuna. Â£1 each and a great experience. Donâ€™t get a taxi take the train!,

If you donâ€™t have train tickets Iâ€™d recommend you purchase tickets as soon as you arrive in Sri Lanka. You can purchase tickets for train travel in the future. The ticket lines can be a bit chaotic but hold your place in line.

Ignore ALL advice that trains are fully booked in advance. Go to the counter which states "All Tickets" and buy a ticket on the day for the journey you want. They are unlikely to be full, but could be busy (Colombo to Habarana isn't). Second class is fine. Check in seat61.com for more on timings. The Tourist Office next door was misleading (and pretty dishonest). AVOID IT!

My husband and I thought we would try something different and take a train from Colombo to Kandy for an overnight stay. We read all the do's and don'ts of riding on the train and thought we were well prepared. WRONG!!! No amount of preparation could ever prepare a person for the sheer madness and chaos of this place! We arrived a good hour before boarding time and tried to get 1st class tickets but they were sold out. No big deal so we got 2nd class. Stood waiting for the train and the moment those doors opened it was nothing but pushing & shoving with people trying to get on to grab a seat. I lost my husband in all the chaos but found him and thankfully he secured 2 seats for us...or so I thought! A guy who I guess was in charge of crowd control & placement stood in front of my seat not letting me sit down next to my husband and kept pointing to the next car. Then a young 20ish yr old girl boards and he puts her in my seat! My husband & I argued that no she wasn't sitting there but he completely ignored us. He then called to security and the security told the girl to stay!!!! Not too sure, but we suspect she might have bribed them to give her a seat. My husband was so upset as was the gentleman behind us who witnessed the entire thing,both began telling the girl off but no way would she move. My husband told me to come and sit by the window and he sat in the middle between the girl and I on 2 seats. It was a very long and uncomfortable & crowded ride. Too many people crammed into a very small space. I don't know how an elderly person or someone with a physical disability could travel this way and if they do then bless them!!

The Fort Railway station is the central train station in Colombo with direct services to the main provincial towns such as Kandy, Jaffna and Nuwara Eliya. The station is near the Pettah which is a busy and bustling market place, well worth exploring. The station itself has seen better days and could do with some TLC.

I frequently visit here to pick friends and to travel. Although outside of the station is a bit awkward inside is quite clean and you will only be disturbed by the announcements from time to time. I even used to read books and do stuff on my laptop seated on the 9th & 10th platforms when trains were late. You need to buy a platform ticket for Rs.10/- to enter the railway station to pick someone or even to say goodbye. There's a bookshop inside the station where you will find things with info on Sri Lanka. The setback of the premises is huge and nice. They have maintained it in a superb way keeping flower pots and stuff.

The station itself is very very basic. However this post is in relation for tourists using the 'tourist information' which is not just for information but booking travel. We used this for our travels around Sri Lanka, as had a lot of distance to cover in not that much time (2 weeks). Now we may have been slightly done of the price (70 pounds per person for 5). But our trip included and a/c van and driver for Colombo to hikkaduwa then to aruganbay, ella and then to kandy. We also had an OBSERVATION carriage booked for the beautiful train ride from Ella to Nanuoya as well. All dealt through Prasanna Ferdinando (tour assistant) we were happy for the majority of the package. However, he tried to screw us for a little extra. Firstly, lying about the exchange rate (he called the bank to to prove he was right and shown to be completely and utterly wrong). This was to gain that little extra from us which he gave up on as he said we had given the him a 'headache' (all very embarrassing and rude). Secondly, instead of buying the tickets for the observation carriage for the later part of the trip in Ella (1000 rupees each ticket), he got us the 3rd class tickets (400 rupees each or less). Finding this out a couple of days before, a stern call to Prasanna meant out driver bought the tickets and gave them to us when he returned to pick out bags us at Ella while we got the train. That said our driver was a legend and a good laugh. This made up for poor experience with Prasanna.

Review Title: Worst experience unsafe experience of colombo to Kandy train
Review Text: Very poor experience if you want to experience jumps opt for this .... I booked observation class and too hot .... Must say they should learn to modify their train facility .. Not recommend for pregnant ladies not safe very poor I will say worst service.
We took the train towards Anuradhapura from here. You can book 2nd class only there will be no airco
The main station I regularly commute. Station is pretty okay. There are some vendors,cafeteria and men's and women's. But the smells from the washrooms can not be bearable everyday.

The Colombo fort railway station functions in a very old not so big colonial structure.  The premises was crowded all the time.  Outside is the roadside bus terminus from where buses can be had to different part of Colombo city. An important junction for both trains and buses in Colombo.
Usual mad station. Well organised for getting the train and plenty of tuk tuks outside. The best thing for me was the Olcott statute outside which is obviously still revered.

You need to take a train to NANU OYA which is the station closest to the Hill Station of Nuwara Eliya.  The ride is the most scenic you will probably experience in this part of the world, with mountains, waterfalls, and lots and lots of greenery.  It really is a wonderful train ride, on a not so comfortable train, but if you can get tickets on the Tourist Scenic Car with it's relatively large windows, you will really, really enjoy it.  By the way, trains in Sri Lanka cost next to nothing!!!

On the first day of our trip, we went to the Colombo Fort Railway's tourist information office. The manager Prassana helped us with scheduling our itinerary and providing a private driver for the whole trip (7 days). Lahiru was our driver's name and we couldn't imagine having another driver than him. He took his time to stop at every interesting places and explain a lot of things concerning the Sri Lankan culture. He provided all the help we needed during our vacation across Sri Lanka. I highly recommend Prassana's tour and ask for Lahiru if possible!
