Review Text: Except the colonial architecture , the place is very badly maintained. I guess this is a problem with Sri Lankan transportation system in general. They could have done a lot with this place as a tourist destination if it was properly maintained.

Had a cold beer here most nights while in Tangalle. Nice and cold and cheap. First night I had the fresh fish. which was Barracuda, and mine was great. My partner had the Deviled Squid which she wasn't keen on. We had them give us a special Sri Lankan chicken curry the next night, which to be honest, wasn't that good. Lovely people and certainly worth a beer and a feed.

Went to Colombo for a price giving function it was late when we arrived there so I planned to change my dress In waiting room The room is nice but the washroom is very bad so I didnâ€™t used that and some place there is untidy

The station itself is clean but be careful of the touts who are not all that innocent! The area is surrounded by dodgy looking shops and the worst Tuk Tuk drivers in the world! (Sri Lankan Tuk Tuk drivers are a bad name for Sri Lankan's all over the world!) Train journeys to Kandy / Galle etc are cheaper than taxis and the first class journeys are 'ok'! But they are very very bumpy! The trains however leave on time and are safe. Make sure to visit Booth number 7 before buying any tickets!
The rail station gives off the aura of the old colonial period with old facilities and old trains. Cool place to have a look about!

Despite the overwhelming first impression, it's easy to get to grips with this place. Yes it's busy, noisy and hot, nothing to make you feel unsafe though. Helpful railway tourist office gave us clear and helpful information and advice on the trains to Galle. Finding which platform was quite straight forward, always a helpful person to point you in the right direction, they always make me suspicious thinking they want something in return, they don't and are just being helpful (and making me feel guilty afterwards for thinking everyone is trying to rip us off). The interior of the station is quite grey and drab. Very noisy with trains coming and going as you would expect. The journey to Galle was great though. We got the first class tourist train. Was t much first class about it though other than aircon (that didn't work) and am assigned seat. No food or drinks on the train so be aware and come prepared. The journey was great though and the fact the aircon wasn't working was actually good as meant we could open the windows and get a much better view of the lovely costal scenery. Really recommend the Journey and a trip by train if you are in Colombo and want to get out of town.

Local markets and stations show the real nature of local culture. Without exorbitant entrance fee ;-)) Just sitting there, watching the hustle and wustle and the small vendors while waiting for your tuk tuk driver to pick you up. That took a while, but then, you have different entrances both sides, somewhat confusing. And an experience a Westerner only cautiously attempts: here you HAVE to walk over the tracks to get to the main hall. This station adjoins the pittoresque Pettah Market.

Colomboâ€™s main train station is very easy to navigate and it is the gateway to a number of cities in the country. I took the train from here to Galle and the whole process was easy, painless and quick. There is a left luggage facility which is very cheap and convenient and some places to eat. Next to the station there is a big market if in need of t-shirts, clothes, adaptors, etc. The trains are a bit old but comfortable and well maintained. The ticket staff is so friendly and helpful!

this is the main place in srilanka. you can get all transport here. and if you want to know the railway schedule you can srch in google. for a example ( colombo to kandy train schedule) then you can get the all train time with the price. more info any help contect me +94779992177. this place have free wifi but its doesn't work good.

We travelled by train a lot in Sri Lanka. So we used this station several times. It looks like chaos, but once you get near the platforms, you can ask about platform numbers, times etc. Beware taxi and tuktuk/taxi touts when you leave the station. Walk at least 100m away before flagging down.

It took me around 45 mins to get to the station from CMB airport. I booked the ticket in advance, The staff and conductors of the station were friendly and helpful, the train moved exactly at the time stated in the ticket but it arrived at the destination around 1 hour late than that was it supposed to. I took the Colombo Fort-Habarana train. The train is a great way to enjoy the green beautiful sceneries of Sri Lanka, tickets are cheap but booking through 3rd part website makes it like x3 times more expensive. Train is not really suitable If you have an oversized luggage, It will be hard moving through corridors. And Donâ€™t expect luxury trains.

The Observation salon (non A/C) was very classy and the view was amazing for people sitting right at the end of the train. Second class seats were comfortable and had a less stuffed atmosphere, and although it's less cleaner than the Obs salon, it's definitely worth its cheaper price. (price gap over Rs.500) Vendors come to the observations salon as well with fruits/water. Seats are reclinable, but some are broken down a bit. CONS- Although the best view is at the rear end, towards noon it gets very sunny and the window glass is fixed shut in that row. The seats at the other end of the compartment are cooler, but the odour from the washrooms are strong, especially when the compartment door is kept open. There was a 2 hour train delay in our train; keep in mind when making plans.
The Colombo Fort Railway is easily accessible by buses from various parts of the city. Once you're here, you can easily purchase tickets to wherever your next destination is...

We imagine that the process of purchasing train tickets has not changed here for a century. It is kind of charming really but you must have patience and remember that it is best to plan ahead by a few days. Otherwise you may find that "you can't always get what you want" as the Stones put it but we did eventually find what we needed. First class tickets sell out rather quickly. especially for morning departures to popular places like Kandi.
It looks old but attractive and having a old days charm from outside. As loke other railways stations it was crowded but we enjoyed even in the rain.

When we visited Sri Lanka, this train station was a bit of a hub for us.  We had to make several stops, and one departure through this train station, and each time we commuted it was a learning experience.  The first thing we learned was don't trust anybody when it came to where your train was leaving, sometimes not even your ticket.  The only people that seemed to know which platform our train was leaving was a group of def people that would help you find your train, and help with your bags, then demand a large tip. Cleanliness was also a second thought in this station, it was so bad that I didn't dare use the bathrooms from the smell alone. There also isn't much as far as places to get snacks or a meal if you're transferring.  Best to go outside and enjoy some of the street kiosks if you can instead. Security was also pretty non-existent, unless you're a traveler. It seems that if you have a bag, a ticket, and look confused security will stop and make sure you're not breaking into the station.  However if you're a random person selling something, a scam artist, illegal cab driver, or any other person you're welcome to come in no questions asked. The reason this station doesn't get a completely poor review is that it's a pretty nice building.  Under the layers of dust it's pretty interesting.  I took a few pictures there that really are spectacular.  Notionally you'll need a train ticket to take these pictures, but if you don't have a ticket, security might just let you through anyways.

After a month of traveling by train in Myanmar, where train workers were super helpful, we encountered the ticket people at Colombo's train station, some of the rudest and unhelpful workers we encountered on our three month journey through Asia. It's confusing which counter you go to ... and once we bought our tickets to Matara, and caught the train a day or two after, we were chagrined to discover the train was already full when it arrived to the Central Station, and we had to stand a long time. Not the entire way, but until a good many people got off. It seemed like a typical experience. No one seemed surprised, and other reviewers mention it, too, in their reviews. The train station is in about the same area as the bus station, which makes for major traffic congestion, depending on when you go. The good news is this was the most annoying train station (I think) we encountered in Sri Lanka, so if you successfully maneuver this obstacle, it's downhill all the way.
Old station but importantly serve it's purpose, daily commute for many & surprisingly punctual too albeit very crowded during rush hours... hanging outside the train!

There is lots of talk on this thread about scamming tuk tuk drivers. If you are at all concerned about this you can use Uber, for a tuk tuk or a car. Myself and my partner have been using Uber a lot in Colombo and Galle and though the local tuk tuk drivers donâ€™t like it you can get a much better idea of prices for journeys. Sure you are probably paying more than local price but in reality this might amount to $1. Itâ€™s even possible to use Uber Intercity, though tolls are extra on top of the quoted Uber price. Most of the drivers weâ€™ve had a young and courteous and a trying very hard to please.

Train travel whilst in Sri Lanka is a must.  Much more pleasant than catching the buses but having continuity in ticket prices and bookings does not exist.  First class gives you air conditioning and generally a seat (not too crowded) but best to only have carry-on luggage.  Third class is as many people as possible in.  There are loads of deaf people who come to the station to help tourists find their way around.  They then expect donations for their services.

This is where most trains pass through and most long distance start from , there are a few enquirers counters , in day time there is a small office where travellers can get help Book in advance for cross country trains in the reservation room , local train counters etc are all in English a large LCD screen shows times platforms destinations now Keep your bags with you at all times itâ€™s busy busy place , avoid rush hours where many thousands commuters come in and out of the city Watch out for tuk tuk drivers outside , if you need transport onwards insist on a meter cab / 3 wheeler Enjoy itâ€™s an experience

The minute one walks into the Fort Railway Station you are transported 50 years or so back. It was built in 1908 and did not appear to have had any upgrading work done. I was told it had 10 platforms and steps and a bridge connecting to these. One modern aspect is the display screen but one could not trust whether the information was accurate. It was very noisy, sometimes painful to the ear as each train entered and left the platform. One could hardly hear the other speaking. Maybe I am old and sensitive to this noise. There were security/ticket checkers sitting at entry and exit points. However it was easy to push through the crowds and enter the station without any checking. Inside the station, there were some seats but not enough for the number of passengers waiting. Our train was to Jaffna leaving at 5.45 am. I wanted to check something about my ticket. There were no information or ticket counters inside. However there was a room where several men were seated behind their desks. There were no computers, everything done manually. If you expect western standards you may think the men were not interested and unhelpful. However, this is the way it seems things are in Srilanks, there are no queues and people tend to push with the 'me first' attitude. I did get my answers to my questions but also advice that one of the trains I had booked my return journey was a slow train taking 10 hours. I was grateful for this information and was able to change my ticket. Unlike airports there are porters to help with your luggage I did not see any porters here. I actually loved this antique railway station.

I had a trip from Colombo to Kandy. It was pre booked. Train arrived on time and had a wonderful & safe journey. Gate ticket checker was polite and willing to give directions . But inside the station was not properly maintained, managed. Toilets were disappointing. Food stalls were really busy and they didnâ€™t care about their customers. I bought 02 noâ€™s of vegetable roti from one of stalls which was close to platform 02. I was so disappointed to say one vegetable roti was spoiled.Both had different fillings as well.I brought that matter to stall owner, it seemed he didnâ€™t care. All they need money and they have an enough flow of customers.May be that might be the reason.Please stop selling spoiled foods. Kind enough to give value for money. At least not to argue. Used plastic bottles, plastic bags were scattered everywhere. It seems nobody cares. An ambience of the station must upgrade, facilities should also update as station is not only visited by locals but also  by foreigners as well. Food stalls should be audited for food safety plus security. For your reference. Thank you for everyone who helped.

This station serves the entire Sri Lanka very well. But if yo are a Traveler who are going to use this, be ready. This is not a very clean and tidy place. This station is very crowded. Specially 6.30 a.m. to 6.30 p.m. How ever there are facilities to book long distance trains. So allays book your train. Most of the times trains goes as scheduled.

Important advice - get here with plentyof time to spare!  There are people everywhere, trains coming and going, bewildered tourists wandering around, locals cramming ontop carriages and no signs or announcements which platifrm your train departs from.  You need to find someone official looking in a uniform and ask which platform your train leaves from and then probably get a second opinion!  As I said, a great travel experience.
There are several trains bound to countryside. So you can find your way through train which is very cheap compared to other form of transpotation.There is  counter to reserve ticket in advanced too.

This is the main train station in srilanka. but it is horrible place to see. very unclean and no facilities for foreigners also for locals. staff are very lazy and they don't inform very well. very disappointed place to have a tickets to go badulla.

We were expecting the worst based on the mixed reviews on TA but to our surprise it was ok. The station was clean, very busy and hot with very few amenities. Signs are not cleared but there are enquiries counters which will aptly guide you. For our case, we were directed to counter no 17 (berth/intercity/reservation/Expo Rail) which essentially is a small air conditioning room. Inside this room, just queue at the respective ticket counter. We showed our pre booked Expo Rail reservation no on mobile (no print out required) and our boarding ticket issued. In fact you can pickup the pre booked Expo Rail boarding ticket before your scheduled departure from 6am-4pm daily (note: counter 17 close lunch time 12.30pm-1pm). Aside on Expo Rail was excellent. Clean, comfortable A/C ride, with free wifi, clean toilet, snacks, bottled water and movie. Heading towards Kandy on Coach 3, best seat 2, 4, 10 on the right with big window. Others have 2 smaller windows. Seat 5 has no window. 3 star for the station, 5 star for Expo Rail.

This is an old-style railway station with nine platforms. There are separate toilets (accessible by key) for foreigners.  The male 'general' public toilets weren't spotless, but they were far from the worst I've seen in Asia. The station can be very busy as hordes of commuters use it. Long distance trips such as to Badulla or (shorter) Kandy are extremely scenic.  Fares are cheap, and some trains have openable windows that are preferable to air conditioned carriages. There are some shops, and provided one takes the usual precautions with smartphones and wallets/purses/bags, the station area is safe. Staff are helpful though the level of English proficiency varies.

One of the main down turns is the very discourteous staff from Ticket collectors to the booking office. They have forgotten that it is the "PASSENGER" whose fare pays them their salary. To them the passenger is a botheration. They glorify in the 8.30 to 4.30 job they do, like the man just mechanically issuing tickets, the person who announces train arrivals or departures merely stating a train is cancelled not bothering to inform what time the next train would be. It is a rudderless leaderless place  with a station master who prefers to remain invisible.

All the trains starts to costal line, up country , North trains starts from colombo fort. There is booking facility also. They announce all trains in English too. So it is convienient to travellers. There is canteen and washroom facilities too, if you are a foreign there is one special washroom facility in platform no 1.  In evening and morning this station is very busy.

Colombo Fort Railway Station is the main Railway head in Colombo. The station building is a colonial era building, which appears to have stuck in the 1980s. For this reason, it has an old world charm to it. It is a relatively small station, however, since Sri Lanka does not have a vast or elaborate rail network, the stations serves the purpose quite well. It is a busy station and appeared crowded. Station itself is maintained neat and clean. The railway staff at the station is quite helpful towards the tourist.

For the foreign traveller arriving first time at Fort Railway station, looking for luxury travel may have to rethink again! Fort is hot and chaotic and once you enter the railway station, one cannot escape the experience outside to the similar experience inside.  There is a sense of urgency about everything and yet without the rush. Trains depart to a different timetable to the listed departure time adding a memorable experience to your travels, but not if you are in a hurry to get to work! The good news is that in the midst of all the hustle & bustle, the system works. The best part of the train journey is chugging along the scenic coastal route. I urge any traveller who is brave enough to take a train ride from Fort to various island destinations to experience the train ride as well as enjoy the sites along the coastal route. If you are brave enough, you can also taste various local food carried up and down the carriages by local food traders.  Taking a train journey from Colombo Fort, should be a mandatory experience by all travellers!

To travel by train is a turistic attraction in Sri Lanka. Than why not to start here. You can buy cheap and expensive tickets here - there are turist agencies for special trains here. The building of the railway station is nothing extra, but this is the main train station to everywhere - than a goog starting point to travel. The trains are always late and there are no information boards to know which train is which. But there are some local people to help you (they understand the only srilankan announcements) to know which is your train - naturally for money, then give them a tip.
The hub in Colombo for trains and the place can be very crowded with people travelling to many destinations in the country. Advanced reservations are required for special seating's.

The local train is a smart way to travel within Colombo, especially when one is not pressed for time. The Colombo Fort station is located next to the Pettah market and is walking distance from the Port area as well.
busy & main station in sri lanka. full of people but that is ok. luggage room is quite small but staff is kind enough. cheap price for luggage store. good

Drop off in front of the station, 10 platforms, and several matrix signs with departure information. Multiple small vendors, benches to sit on the platforms, and free of charge toilets spotted at platform 1 (I didn't check them out, do no idea of the state).

If you want to see Sri Lanka then you must take three train rides one to Kandy the ancient capital the other to Newra Eliya and the other trip to Galle all along the coast be prepared for a trip of over 21/2 hours ,the trip to Kandy will take just as long as they stop at every station and its an event in itself with all the hawkers offering you all sorts of short eats , you can get first class seats or do the backpacker thing and go with the natives the train is always full so you can end up standing all the way the scenery is breathtaking and the trip to Nera Eliya 69000 feet up is a  must its just one of those things you need to add to the 100 list befor you depart this beautiful earth the only living planet in our solar system. do not worry you will return to dust from which you came and  be resting till the resurrection .

I have been to the for railway station many times. The service we get from teh staff at thr railway station is good but needs to improve. I would be much happier if they could smile and be a little bit more friendlier to us.
Heritage at its best. We took a train to Kandy and amazing is mere a word. Old world charm by well managed.

If you have already planned your stay you should be fine, it is an average rail station. However if you are a tourist who looks remotely lost you will be escorted to a local travel agency where they will meticulously help you plan your trip and then inflate the price a ridiculous amount. Please don't make the same mistake we made.

We went to the station to inform ourselve of the schedule and price for the train to Hikkaduwa.  Sadly we couldn't take it from a station stop near our hotel, we had to leave from the main station. It's a very big station but pretty well organize, it's easy to get information and buy tickets to go where your want. The train seems all to be on time too. That day we took the local train back to our hotel, it was only a short ride but it's was fun, the track along the ocean makes it a nice scenery and it's pretty cheap, it's worth trying it
Easy to find and people are very helpful. But inside bit dirty. Although few displays are not showing the information number of display boards are there to find train time tables
went to the place very bussy area  lot of people waiting to travel directions are not clear to buy tickets at the station they change to counters  very often

Donâ€™t even bother. We got dropped off by the tuk tuk at the back of the station and directed around the front to the ticket counters. In our daze and confusion we were beckoned into the tourist information centre and relaxed thinking we were about to receive some help and direction. However, what we got was some guy making what I have come to believe is a bogus phone call to check on train tickets for us to Anuradapura. He then proceeded to offer us a package deal including driver and accommodation for Â£70 a day!!! He showed receipts from other travellers before us and everything. We were hesitant so were encouraged to check trip advisor because he has nothing but excellent reviews. Jokes on him, scam scam scam. We declined and we are so glad we did. We got seated tickets on our desired train and, despite him telling us the Kandy-Ella train was fully booked, we got standing tickets on the day. Avoid the tourist information guy, the train station itself is fine. Exactly what you would expect from a busy Sri Lankan city.
went to see th e busiest place in colombo the indian and SBI are there. and people are pouring in all roads. the traffic is well controlled and so it is easy for hr pedestrais to cross the road.

We walked to the station, asked where to buy a train ticket and got pointed in the right direction. Five minutes later I had our 2nd class tix to Kandy for a few bucks. Easy as pie and the train arrived and departed on time. It is a long bumpy ride but you will have some great scenery to enjoy as well as people to meet on the train.
Its the main Railway station of Colombo from where you can get Sub Urban and Long Distance Trains... Located in the heart of Colombo...Old Colonial Building...
